content.title: History
paragraphs: A new world usually rises when the old one falls. It is not often that the old world eats the new world to birth the monstrous amalgamation of both. Edenfell used to be very different; a world in which magic was ordinary, a multitude of races coexisted in negotiated peace and harmony, battle was a distant memory and youthful death was an elusive concept, the extraordinary was both gentle and magnificent, nature cared for the Anthros and in return, the Anthros cared for nature.

This paradise which seems like a tall tale was lost when a party of kings and mages alike stepped into the unknown on a mission to investigate a world beyond a rift that had opened between this realm and another; Limbo. The ancient Limbo, a realm far older than Edenfell, in which the spiteful deity Nimiane had been confined, imprisoned by the Old Gods, her siblings, was a caustic place hungry for life and for mana, the fuel of magic. Ultimately unsuccessful in their quest to banish Nimiane and close the rift between the two worlds, Limbo quickly consumed these storied explorers and in time, it consumed Edenfell too, spilling out its toxicity in waxing tides that soon engulfed everything as far as the eye can see, forever changing the world as we all know it. This is what we have come to call the Cataclysm.

Now, Edenfell is a land of scarce magic, perilous forests, vengeful beasts, floating islands, and the harsh reality of man’s failure. Conflict is common, betrayal is the currency of the living, and death is as certain as the sunrise.
The burning question I ask you is this: what will you make of this new world? What will you do? Do not just survive, Edener…live!

content.title: Lore
paragraphs: When the Cataclysm ended, Fëanor alone emerged as the sole survivor among those who had gone to take on Nimiane. He stepped foot on Ground Zero, welcomed by a world that he no longer recognized and could not save—a world enveloped by the same malevolent force of hunger and destruction that pervaded Limbo and overrun by monsters the new world would christen Voidbringers.

Nimiane did not enter Edenfell herself, but it was no man’s doing because none could have stopped her. Her rancorous spirit, however, fed on the land and the soil and the crops and the air and the water, and soon, it was a world reshaped in Limbo’s image. Edenfell’s glorious civilizations fell; Summerwind, Alfenheim, Vanaheim, Ironhold, and Viridi, the 5 Old Nations of myth crumbled in the wake of the Voidbringers; and the Anthros themselves were forever changed; lifespans were drastically reduced, magic was almost entirely stolen from man, and entire races were wiped off the face of Edenfell for good.

It has been two hundred years since the Cataclysm now and the Anthros are struggling to rebuild. Most plants, like the beasts, turned noxious and posed a threat to the people so that only a few could be depended on for food in a world where the soil could no longer yield new life. The Anthros returned to their hunter-gatherer roots, surviving as foragers and livestock herders, and building settlements where the climate was just conducive enough to ensure that they could somewhat thrive. Soon cities began to spring up where subsistent wildlife was most bountiful (and Voidbringers were not) and the modern world as we know it took shape:
Obscuron was left desolate, the desecrated and ravenous location of Ground Zero.

Durlan in the south became Fëanor’s foothold, kept functional by the plethora of taxed villages and settlements around it. It is a stronghold where he intends to build an army of mages (the Higher Sentient) charged with growing their numbers (forcefully), erecting the most magnificent edifice of the new world—a city that is a worthy ode to the Old Nations—and reclaiming Edenfell for man, magic, and the Old Gods.

Caliburn, Vatha, and Edom formed the Trident cities in the north that shelter the world’s diverse population from the prowling Voidbringers and form the most formidable resistance to the Higher Sentient’s Marauders, The United Army (UnA or colloquially the Yuna). The Trident is a place most survivors dream of reaching but the distance between the north and the south is vast and filled with dangers that do not just make it a near-miraculous journey and a place almost like a legend to wistful settlers around the continent but also keeps it outside of the reach of Durlan’s long and authoritative (though well-intentioned) shadow. But the Trident is not perfect, and as it grows it becomes rife with political intrigue, racial tensions, disgruntled commoners and perhaps soon, there may be a few uprisings in the plot.

They say there are two sides to every story, but in Edenfell there is no shortage of sides to choose from. Align yourself with a cause and fight its battle to completion or choose your own cause, play one side, both sides, or none. Always remember, you make your own way, and whatever that is, I am certain your legend will shape this new world.

content.title: Edenfell’s Anthropomorphic Races (Anthros)
paragraphs: Before the Cataclysm, Edenfell presumably had more races of Anthros (Gaians, Merfolk, Centaurs, Orcs, etc), but that age is long past and the handful of survivors who lived in that time—before the death and extinction of races that could not cope with a world without excess magic—are now also long gone themselves and the stories are nothing more than an oral relic of a past no one remembers or ever witnessed. The 4 races that remain are as diverse and colorful as they could ever be, however, and bring a variety of cultures, temperaments, history, and magic to the world that it would otherwise be dull without.
Here are Edenfell’s last remaining Anthro races in no particular order:

content.title: The Elves (Alfen)
paragraphs: Sometimes referred to pejoratively as skinny Nords, the Elves of Edenfell are Nord-like in physical appearance, save for a few key differences. Elves are often smaller than Nords, with sharper, pointier ears. They follow the general stereotypes you’re all used to; there is no need to explain what we all know. The Elves have often always had the closest connection to Edenfell’s magic in the past being the first of the Anthros, this is why in the past Alfen Mages had more mana and magical aptitude than their peers and it explains why, even now in the age where Mages are a rarity, most of them tend to be Elves.

While it’s immoral to subject the entire race to a few stereotypes, we’re going to do so anyway. The Elves tend to be very traditional, proud, condescending, and patronizing. Turning their noses up at other cultures and practices, they argue the importance of their existence and how they are the most civilized of all races.
Alfen often spot tattoos and paint on their bodies that can be anything from sentimental and tribal to religious or superstitious.

Like all the other Anthros, Elves have a natural racial ability we’re going to call a Trait. The Alfen trait allows them to communicate at a frequency that other Anthros and most living beings cannot hear—even a Changeling with sensitive hearing would have difficulty picking it up. In addition to this, Elves have enhanced senses; their taste, smell, sight, touch, and obviously hearing are heightened and much better than most—second only to some animals. On average, they stand at about 185cm (6’1”) for men and 175cm (5’9”) for women.

Elven Mages are known for their elemental magic; water, earth, fire, lightning, tallow & air. It is possible for Elves to “specialize” in a certain element, and be able to develop it to a new level. A fire specialist might be able to develop into magma or even explosives/combustion. But this takes time, and skill to unlock. Elves are known for their carpentry and weaponsmithing. Their weapons tend to be more “elegant”, like a saber or rapier, rather than brutish, like a broadsword. Despite this, they’re well-known for their skills in archery, and this is what most are trained in. When it comes to armor, they tend to keep it light and simple as the general combat style of the elves is very “hit and run” or “long-ranged”.

Elves used to be known for their long lives, living up to almost 1000 years of age. But after the Cataclysm, this has changed. Their average age range, for one reason or another, began to match the rest of the races—that being an average of 80 years old. Despite being just like the rest now, they still think they’re better.

Certain slurs are considered offensive or hurtful by the Elves: Faeries or Fairies, Knife-ears, Twinks, and Pricks. They also really hate being called “Faes” (it’s the equivalent, to them, of being called a Neanderthal to us).

content.title: The Fae (Faeries)
paragraphs: Faes are a race of Elven heritage that used to be natives of the forests and the woods. The Fae used to rarely ever venture past the woods due to their timid and reserved nature and were once even considered a myth, like cryptids.

Stereotypically, Faes, like the Elves, are rarely cooperative—but not for the same reason. Elves are much more offish, vain, and conceited while the Faes are skittish, bashful, and sometimes considered cowards due to their peace-loving nature. Faes are usually incredibly peaceful and tend to focus more on themselves rather than the problems of others. Though not as ethnocentric as Elves, they try their best to avoid the affairs of the other races and just focus on themselves. Faes are sort of like green Elves (though they can be pale, brown, or even have ordinary pigmentation like the Elves), they have the ears and the youthful effeminate face and everything—they just have more chlorophyll.

Faes have a natural race trait that allows them to do a few things. What they’re most well known for, and the most convenient trait, to be honest, is the ability to create wings. The wings grant the Faes flight (no way!), allowing them to fly or hover at a low altitude (no higher than an average tree). They also have the ability to shrink themselves to a size of a smaller dog, like a baby Yorkie. Obviously, they can also return to their original size, which on average is 170cm (5’7”) for men and 160cm (5’3”) for women. Some Faes may have horns, antlers and other such protrusions on their heads.

Fae Mages are able to utilize the power of plants around them. This entails many things when it comes to usage. For example, Faes are able to temporarily sprout plants from seeds, they’re able to sense nearby plants in the vicinity and control them as well. They have an innate understanding of which plant does what, they’re able to move plants without killing them, wither plants, resuscitate them, etc. Faes are incredibly skilled to an almost mesmerizing degree at music, the arts, carpentry, and tinkering, and while they used to be incredibly adept farmers during the age of agriculture, they are just as good hunters and foragers in this new age of seeking and gathering food.

Slurs considered offensive or hurtful by the Faes: Vires (it's their n-word), Tree Hugger, and the rest of the Elven slurs. They hate being called Elves, as well—they think they’re better, but they’ll never admit it.
Fun fact: instead of melanin, they say chlorophyll.

content.title: The Nords (Warborn)
paragraphs: Having evolved to withstand the harsh nature and adapt to most—if not all—environmental challenges, Nords have a storied history as battle-drunk veterans who are constantly looking for a fight. Despite this, they also tend to have an insatiable desire for knowledge and discovery, having once built the single greatest and most expansive library and school in Edenfell. The Nords once traversed land and sea—conquering nations, and so it is no surprise that they have survived the Cataclysm and will likely overcome this new obstacle yet again. The Nords prefer colder settings rather than warmer climates and so they have always gravitated to the north.

Stereotypically, Nords are easily prone to anger or just temperamental, often willing to settle disputes with their fists before any more words are exchanged. You would be hard-pressed to find a Nord with bare skin as most of them are adorned in tribal marks, tattoos, stories told in colorful ink, and scars borne proudly like testaments of one’s strength and experience in battle and life in general.

Nords are physically the strongest of the races. Able to wrestle bears and tigers down to submission, it isn’t a far stretch to claim that they could overwhelm most with their bare fists alone. But with this clear advantage, they also do have a weakness; in terms of magic, they are not the most potent. They have low mana and tend to focus on a “might over magic” type of fighting style. Nords yield fewer mages than the other races, and this has always been the case throughout antiquity. Their physique is usually hulking, and the same goes for their stature. The men average 200cm (6’7”) in height, and the women average 185cm (6’1”).

Even though Nords are more strength than wizardry, there are some Mages amongst them. Their magic consists of a “creation” type of magic, which can simply be described as construction magic. This magic is called Conjuration (Crafting). The constructs that they create are limited only by their imagination and their mana. While they cannot simply create a full-sized living dragon that breathes fire (not at first anyway), they are able to create constructs of different items such as tools and weapons that cannot simply be broken by being struck with just some force.

Nords are exceptional hunters, herders, and rearers of livestock as well as good sailors and blacksmiths. They are also often quite skilled at woodworking and building ships and structures, usually of the sturdy, sheer, and austere kind.
Slurs considered offensive or hurtful by the Nords: Bone-bag, Meathead, Sunflower (pejorative for their often golden hair), Snow Angel

content.title: The Changelings (Spiels)
paragraphs: Upon first interacting with one of these guys, it’s possible that you might not even notice that it’s a Changeling. You can only know if the Changeling wants you to know—and that’s what is so unique about this race. This alludes to many things, but mainly to their nature. Changelings are often very tricky and mischievous individuals! They tend to go out of their way to cause trouble for others and have a generally competitive nature. Changelings are differentiated by their animalistic features, which vary depending on the Changeling themself. They can have a tail, some ears, claws, and be generally humanoid—or they can be on the opposite end of this spectrum and just be, physically, an anthropomorphic animal.

Changelings are matriarchal, and therefore women tend to be much stronger and bigger than men. Obviously, due to the variety of Changelings as a result of the amount of different animalistic hybrids that can exist, the average size changes often and is not very accurate. However, the estimated difference between men and women in Changelings is about 20cm. So an avian Changeling (for instance) would have a man stand, on average, 160cm (5’3”) and the women’s average would be 180cm (5’11”). Many different combinations with different heights and sizes depending on the animal kin also exist.

Changelings tend to mimic the personality of the animal they kin, so a tiger would be fierce while a rabbit would be timid, but stereotypically, most Changelings are tricky individuals, some to the point of sociopathy—where they hold no regard for the safety of the people they deceive, including their fellow Changelings. While at first, this race might seem like the safest to interact with, due to how cuddly and adorable some of them look, they’re more often than not the most dangerous as they value their own amusement to a higher degree than others’ safety.

Changelings’ trait is dependent on what animal they kin. A cheetah Changeling could be incredibly fast over short distances, a hawk Changeling could have massive wings that they could use to fly, etc. It all depends on which attribute/feature of the animal the Changeling has. Changelings are also able to speak to and understand all animals freely. It is a nifty and interesting gift to have and makes them very good herders and tamers.

Changeling Mages are a different breed completely for they are able to take the form of any beast and animal completely they so please—which allows them to get their natural abilities. Mages of a higher caliber are also able to combine different animalistic features together to transform into some sort of chimera.

There exists some intraracial tension in the Changeling community as a result of the distinct groups that exist within it. Changelings can be split up into six different groups. These groups are Mammals, Aves, Reptiles, Amphibians, Invertebrates, and Fish. Mammals are seen as the top of the food chain among Changelings, and they have their own inner-foodchain amongst them (it exists as a sub-group of predators and prey, which does not need to be explained), Reptiles are considered second, Aves third, followed in order by Amphibians, Invertebrates, and Fish. The latter 3 are regarded as bottom feeders of the Changeling society. Reptiles and Amphibians tend to go together quite often, but the relationships are often kept secret as any Reptile who’s seen with an Amphibian is looked down on as lesser than their peers. Mammals and Aves also sometimes go together (and this union is more tolerated because of their standing as apexes but is still not entirely accepted and considered weird because of the stigma against mixing among Changelings).
Slurs considered offensive or hurtful by the Changelings: Furball, Pigeon, Dunce-kin, Manimal, Pet, Leash-chaser

content.title: Writer’s Notes
paragraphs: Here are some more stereotypes and trivia that are nothing more than heuristics for the players to do with as they please:

paragraphs.text: Elves hate everyone. They’re basically the French people of the races.
Faes tolerate everyone but get annoyed easily by others' “ignorance” of their craft. They tolerate Elves the most.
Nords have no inherent hatred for any of the races, but they do find Elves annoying.
Changelings hate Nords because Nords hunted them for sport.
Nords have a lot of blue-eyed, blond-haired folk
There are no half-breeds in Edenfell. Children of interracial unions will always be the race of the more dominant partner (Elves >> Changelings >> Nords >> Faes)

content.title: What Remains Of Religion?

paragraphs.text: An age ago most of the Anthros in Edenfell, no matter their shapes, sizes, or races believed in the five gods (

of the Ocean). They believed that mortals had been placed as wardens of the realm by these gods as an act of trust and that it was the duty of men to protect this world and serve the gods with their lives.

paragraphs: But that was a different time…

Now, the extent to which one is religious depends entirely on the individual, and in a world rife with danger, wandering evil, and rampant violence in which it easily feels like gods and anything divine and good have long abandoned man, very few hold any faith. Elves remain the least religious race since they still believe themselves to be divine in nature and as such find the entire concept of worship difficult to grasp or justify.

All of the lands used to be influenced by the belief in gods and their tenets in many different ways, therefore, all over the world there are remnants and ruins of shrines, statues, amulets, and temples scattered and often long buried with the rest of what once was.

paragraphs.text: During a recent unsuccessful campaign to divert and neutralize Voidborns that had strayed too close to Caliburn, something occurred that has raised some old questions among those present and skepticism among those who were not. The sighting of

, a massive apparition of sorts that the parties involved claimed helped vanquish the enemy they had failed to beat and were fleeing from, has both cast aspersions on the sanity of the soldiers in question as well as spread whispers about the truth of it all; what is real and what isn’t? Was this a shared fever dream induced by the arcane powers of a potent Voidbringer, or is there something else out there with us?

content.title: What are Voidbringers?
paragraphs: Voidbringers (also called Voidborn) are malicious, mindless, feral magical para-demons that wander grotesquely through the most corrupted parts of Edenfell, taking the decay with them wherever they go. Their ranks consist of all the beings from Nimiane’s world and this one whose mana has been sullied and as such they themselves have been warped and transformed into these terrible marauders. Voidbringers walk around looking for good mana to leech on, eternally hungry for more, and as such they attack people in hordes no matter how little mana the individual possesses and therefore pose a great existential threat to all of Edenfell. Like the characters, these malevolent beings exist in Tiers that determine the level of peril and destruction they may bring with them. It is humanity’s goal to vanquish the Voidborn once and for all because regardless of what side each individual is on, this is a common and deadly enemy.

content.title: The UnA vs. The Higher Sentient
paragraphs: Edenfell was once a land divided into distinct kingdoms segregated on the basis of race, each one of which took pride in their differences and sometimes waged war because of these differences. Magic was shared amongst all the armies of the world, and all these kingdoms were united under one empire under the capital of Ironhold. The Cataclysm brought an end to these kingdoms, and nations could no longer afford to unite under racial identities.

Soon after the Cataclysm, Fëanor started gathering mages under the banner of the Higher Sentient— an organization with the sole purpose of gathering and honing mages to fight against the Voidbringers, no matter the cruelty of their methods— and built Durlan, where the mages are treated like nobility, whilst the non-mages are treated like peasants who run the kingdom. Due to the growing rarity of magic, this has proven to be a difficult task, but the Higher Sentient and Durlan have grown to be a sizable kingdom, dominating the southern end of the continent.

Meanwhile, on the northern end of the continent, 3 separate settlements grew into separate nations, which are now known as the new bastions of a free world, free from the Higher Sentient’s tyranny and from the Voidbringers’ terror, where any one can claim their rightful place in society, mage or non-mage. These three cities— Caliburn founded by the Elves, Vatha by the Nords, and Edom by the Changelings— are collectively known as the Trident and are still composed predominantly of the races that founded them, but they are all allied against the Higher Sentient, and their armies are combined into a single allied force known as the United Army (UnA, phonetically Yuna).

Caliburn is ruled by a multi-racial council of 10 highly esteemed individuals who are renowned as the best in their domain. Vatha is an absolute monarchy, ruled over by a Jarl who proves himself to be the best. In contrast, Edom is ruled democratically by an ambassador who is chosen by vote and is usually considered as the most diplomatic candidate. The Trident’s greatest strength lies in its abundance of Adam’s Steel weapons, as it lets all non-mage soldiers start off with their own Adam’s Steel weapon (sword, bow, spear, etc.) and a shield, which only gets replaced if it’s lost or destroyed.

In contrast, the Higher Sentient’s army consists only of mages, divided into units including a Mage Seeker— mages specialized in tracking down potential mages— and a well-rounded team of mages to support the seeker. The Higher Sentient is usually involved in patrolling the kingdom of Durlan to ensure that the settlements at the fringes of the kingdom remain safe, and to find any young mages who can be brought to the capital and trained to join its ranks.

content.title: Antler
paragraphs: Antler is a hunting guild officially recognized in the Trident, with complete authority to protect and preserve Edenfell’s wildlife, declare areas and species appropriate for sport hunting, and combat poaching worldwide.

Antler grew due to the favor it received from the various monarchies because the continent’s nobility, regardless of race, has always enjoyed hunting. With its influence, Antler seeks to provide a full understanding and documentation of all creatures in Edenfell and ensure that all species stay extant. Many of the UnA’s members are part of this guild as well and they seek to slowly but steadily add to an increasingly detailed and comprehensive bestiary.
Antler employs ruthless methods in dealing with poachers and their black market profiteers and is either fully backed or allowed to do so by the Trident’s rulers and nobility. You have been warned.

content.title: White Wings
paragraphs: White Wings are large avian magical creatures that can be found all over Edenfell. They thrive in all climates and, as a result, are common to and well-known by all the people of Edenfell. White Wings flock together in large groups of twenty to over a hundred, usually nesting either high in the thickest branches of trees or (more commonly) in the large holes or craters they dig in the ground.

White Wings are incredibly big, and males in the wild can grow up to 20 meters long and 5 meters tall (almost twice the max size of a female). They weigh up to a ton, which is surprisingly light for their size and is a result of their very hollow and low bone density. White Wings get their name from their pristine white feathers that cover their entire bodies bar their scaled talons, beaks and the parallel rows of protruding spikes on their backs. A White Wing’s wingspan is the same as its body length.

White Wings are generally docile and do not attack people unless perceivably threatened. They are carnivorous and feed on small mammals like rodents and large insects or worms, because despite their great size, White Wings require very little sustenance, and an adult male White Wing barely eats more than 1/50th of its weight per day. This nifty trait, along with how easy they are to train, has made them a feature in society as they are the primary means of aerial travel and are most especially used by the aeolian divisions of armies because they can easily fit half a dozen men comfortably strapped down on their backs.
White Wings travel half as fast as Chasers do, which is impressive given their size. White Wing eggs are massive and are a delicacy among the Elves and Nords.

content.title: Chasers
paragraphs: Chasers (or horned Chasers) are magical equine mammals similar in appearance to horses but usually twice as tall (and sometimes large) and many times faster. They have two long black horns on their heads (both males and females), and their skin is covered in a thin layer of crenated carapace with webbed spikes where a horse’s mane would be. Chasers have two muscular prehensile tails, with the larger one folding over the smaller one. They have incredibly powerful legs and can travel up to four times as quickly as a horse would, making them viable and reliable for use in travel and message delivery. Chasers are especially useful in battle as their armoured bodies can resist a little more punishment than a regular horse’s.

Chasers are known for their incredible temperament, and being able to ride one is both a feat of being accepted by the strong and violent creatures, as well as being able to remain on top of them as they speed away. Even with the aid of double-clipping harnesses incorporated into their saddles, most people still do not make it through a ride on one of these without falling or getting extremely nauseous.

They can only be found in Durlan.They do not do well in the cold and may even die quickly when exposed to low temperatures for a short time. Chasers have fangs and are omnivorous. In the wild, they hunt all prey smaller than them, using their horns to great effect.

content.title: Marshland Selkie
paragraphs: Marshland Selkies are the only kind of this magical creature found in the south. They are harmless to people, solitary and feline in appearance, much like their forest counterparts, despite being nothing like cats. Selkies are small (about the size of a domestic cat) and some individuals have horns.

Selkies have silky sable-like fur of different dark hues (most commonly brown and black), webbed and clawed feet, and strong teeth with particularly sharp fangs. They are notorious for their sirens, which can travel great distances, especially at night.

All Selkies are semi-aquatic and their diet consists entirely of fish of all kinds. Like Kai Wings, Selkies are hunted for their fur, and their existence is threatened by the black market for goods made from this poaching, which Edenfell’s hunting guild, Antler, actively combats.
Selkies live, hunt, and mate almost exclusively underwater and usually come up only to graze and play if they encounter another of their kind.

content.title: Courier Bat
paragraphs: The Courier, Quicksilver, or Cakeberry Bat, is a small crimson bat named for its love of the Sidus fruit and its long history of use as a message delivery bat in Vatha and Caliburn. The bats are kept as useful pets and communication through them is not just common but extremely casual, rampant and rapid. Courier Bats are the fastest known creatures in Edenfell and can cover short distances in a matter of seconds. In Caliburn and Vatha, these bats, barely the size of a fist, keep the cities connected and are such a household item to the point that owned bats wear necklaces or annulets that indicate to whom they belong at a glance. It is considered a terrible crime and a stupid one to cause harm to someone’s bat, though the punishment is not that severe.

Courier Bats are immune to poison and illnesses and do not carry or spread any infirmities. This is arguably why they have come to be such a staple of society and why they are considered very magical in nature.

content.title: Teether
paragraphs: Teethers are unsightly bugs with a grubby body of carapace and toothed “fingers” for locomotion that live in trees all over Edenfell. They generally stay high up and are rarely spotted by people, but can sometimes fall from leaves and branches onto a person.

They are pests that damage leaves and bark, hollowing out trees or ruining crops. When left on the body for a prolonged period, they can lead to rot. This can be quickly treated with salves and unguents before it grows fatal, but people are still wary of and detest these things, especially as they can go undetected in hair and clothing for a long time.
Teethers don’t get bigger than a small fist usually, and most are feasted on by Squirrel Kings who are sometimes owned as pets for this reason.

content.title: Selkie
paragraphs: Selkies are harmless to people, solitary and feline in appearance, despite being nothing like cats. Selkies are small (about the size of a domestic cat) and some individuals have horns.

Selkies have silky sable-like fur of different dark hues (most commonly brown and black), webbed and clawed feet, and strong teeth with particularly sharp fangs. They are notorious for their sirens, which can travel great distances, especially at night.

All Selkies are semi-aquatic and their diet consists entirely of fish of all kinds. Like Kai Wings, Selkies are hunted for their fur, and their existence is threatened by the black market for goods made from this poaching, which the hunting guild, Antler, actively combats.

Selkies live, hunt, and mate almost exclusively underwater and usually come up only to graze and play if they encounter another of their kind. They are found mostly in Vatha and higher up north, though they definitely prefer the forest climate to the extreme cold of the mountains.

content.title: Squirrel King
paragraphs: The Squirrel King is an arboreal medium-sized rodent found high up in trees in the woods of Vatha and Edom. They seldom come down to the ground as they are very wary of all kinds of predators. Their prey consists of insects and smaller animals, especially Teethers that also reside in the trees. They look like squirrels (hence the name) but have brightly colored eyes and a “crown” of four feathered prongs on their heads. Squirrel Kings are often tamed and kept as pets due to their loyal nature as well as their lovable appearance. They are capable of cross-breeding with squirrels, though the resulting offspring will always be Squirrel Kings.

content.title: Kai Wing
paragraphs: Kai Wings are solitary predators that stalk the warm regions of Edenfell. They would do well in ever sunny lands but are rarely found there due to their love for trees, fish, and the lack of an abundance of forest prey they enjoy.

Kai Wings look like furry wild cats and grow to about the size of an adult male lion, with a thick tail that can be as long as the rest of their body. Their fur is peppered with feathers around their necks, backs, and haunches. Kai Wing feathers are white with dark blue or black coloration at the ends; this gives their wings a unique shaded appearance. This feature earned them the nickname 'Shadow Cat'. Their wingspan is usually twice the length of their bodies, with each wing a Kai Wing long.

Kai Wings are feral and wild and often attack people unprovoked, even occasionally swooping down to carry smaller people away, much like they do with prey (spawning the Shadow Cat midwives tale). They cannot be tamed and are not seen as pets or companions to domesticate.

Kai Wings have poison in their fangs, and though lethal, this is not potent enough to kill prey as large as a person in a few (5) turns. They are usually only found in the thick woods near Durlan and sometimes a little south of its borders.

content.title: Syphax
paragraphs: A Syphax is a giant reptile (similar in some ways to both a crocodile and a lizard) that is found only on Vatha lands. They can grow to the size of White Wings but weigh considerably more (up to 10 tons) and start much smaller with eggs much smaller than a chicken’s. However, Syphaxes are essentially immortal if not killed or harmed by disease, and therefore generally live longer than White Wings. They live in pairs, usually in large caves and burrows underground.

Syphaxes are dangerous, with long claws and razor sharp teeth lining their maws. They can swallow a man whole and eviscerate people with macabre ease. Despite this, though, they have been adapted for military use owing to their incredible utility as beasts of burden that have saved Edenfell’s armies a lot of effort carrying weapons, food, and supplies to and from battlefields for centuries. Syphaxes are slow, especially when carrying weight around, but can be supremely rapid when hunting or given the command. At their fastest, they can match a Chaser for a short time but do not have the stamina to keep up that acceleration for more than a few seconds.

Syphaxes do not just carry supplies for the Nords but can also move large numbers of men great distances (much more than White Wings can carry). They also serve as tanks due to their great durability and numbness to pain. Syphaxes are often used as part of the Nordic expeditions into dangerous lands like the New Frontier.
Syphaxes eat a great deal due to their fast metabolism, and if left hungry, turning one’s back to them is a grave mistake.

content.title: Bayou Bear
paragraphs: Bayou Bears are large grizzly-like aquatic creatures that live in swamps all around Edenfell. They spend years in the swamp’s murky waters and often grow moss and other greens on their backs that aid their camouflage in these waters.

They swim up to the surface to surprise any prey foolish enough to wander through their habitat, clamping down on the victim to pull it down under where they drown, maul, and then feast on their meal. Bayou Bears make traversing swampland a terrifying prospect in Edenfell. Despite their large size and ferocious nature, however, they are often killed by Kai Wings, who bear an inexplicable animosity towards them. They usually stay hidden underwater when they know one is around.

content.title: Kelpie
paragraphs: Kelpies are shapeshifting water horses only found surfing and riding the waves of the Circle Sea, mainly coming to shore in Durlan and Vatha. They have an opaque appearance and look every bit as they feel, like bodies carved out of pristine, glowing water. They are friendly and have been known to sailors in Edenfell since the dawn of time. They race boats and ships on the sea, come to the rescue of shipwrecks and abandoned people out in the water, and guide those they find to the shore with glee. Kelpies cannot be caught, harmed, or killed because of their nature and many superstitious folk believe them to be spirits, though their behaviour, mating, and other characteristics indicate that they are simply another magical animal.

paragraphs.text: Sea, Shores of Durland and Vatha

content.title: Northern Ox
paragraphs: The Northern Ox is native to northern Vatha and Caliburn and is more like a bison than an ox. It is covered in wooly hair and has two massive, powerful horns. The Northern Ox can dwarf most bears (being twice their size) and even make Kai Wings look small. They are a part of Nord culture and have been used for milk, meat, and as mounts for centuries by kings and commoners alike. The Northern Ox is capable of keeping up with a horse over long distances and can carry its own weight in load on its back. These creatures do not do well in warm climates and are not usually brought further south than Varakis.

content.title: Tigron
paragraphs: The Tigron is a big feline creature with pronounced antlers and a bony face. They are rideable and trainable. Tigrons that survive their first year of life have a good chance of living for another hundred years. The Tigron can be found prowling the forests of Edom and Vatha, as well as the highlands and canyons all over Edenfell. Most prefer temperate or warm environments, but some Tigrons thrive in the northern cold. The horns of some Tigrons are radiant and will give men pause in awe when spotted at night, despite the danger of them. Tigrons are solitary creatures and omnivores, but they rarely hunt people unless threatened or starving.

They are ferocious cats that easily outgrow an adult tiger and Kai Wing and have been known to take on much larger beasts and win. There is an old Nord legend that claims the Jarl Skaldr was so impressed with finding a Tigron that had fought and killed a Syphax to defend her cubs that he made the cats his royal companions.

The Tigron’s roar is deep, guttural, and able to shake a man if he is close by. Tigrons are incredibly wild and dangerous, and their loyalty is hard to win, harder even than that of a Chaser, but it is very much worth the effort.

content.title: Canopy Stalker
paragraphs: Canopy Stalkers are arboreal leopard-like cats with fiery spots and scarlet manes that live in the trees in Durlan and only descend to pounce on prey which they carry back up the trees to feed on. Canopy Stalkers are impressive for the heights from which they can fall without harm and how easily they maneuver whilst midair, almost always managing to land on their feet in a manner that kills their prey.

They have a longer claw on both their forearms that makes climbing great heights easier as well as ensures that killing prey is a matter of a single strike instead of prolonged, exposed battles on the ground. Canopy Stalkers are very quiet creatures, and people often say they have no footfalls even when they descend from the highest branches.

content.title: Willow
paragraphs: Willows (or Dire Willows) are large canine creatures about the size of a grey wolf, or sometimes twice as big, that stalk the edges of the woods in Vatha, Edom and Durlan. They are most often spotted in Edom, where they haunt and hunt any canopy of tall trees. Dire Willows are solitary creatures, usually only seen alone, and notoriously incapable of tolerating other members of their species. These creatures are famous for their appearance, with very contrasting particolor fur and two pairs of short antlers sprouting from their heads. The Willow’s most notable trait, however, is its ability to bend light and camouflage by magical means, becoming transparent by the means of a colorful flame that washes over its body, making it seem to have vanished instantly.

Willows are wild and almost cryptid. They hunt small prey and children who wander too close to the edge of the woods. Willows are capable of psionics and telepathy to an unknown extent. Each Dire Willow has a name, known only to the creature, which it whispers to anyone who survives and maintains extended interaction with it. Speaking the Willow’s name banishes it, returns children it has recently taken, and keeps those around the one who has spoken it safe.

content.title: Owlbear
paragraphs: A mammalian prowler that lives in Durlan’s eastern forests, found only around rivers or creeks, the Owlbear is a rare and endangered species of magical beast whose population has dwindled as a result of hunting and sapien activity in its habitats over the ages.

Owlbears are physically a lot like grizzlies but differ greatly in that they are chimeras with the face of an owl and a mane of feathers, as well as plumage on their forearms and tail. With these features, the heavy Owlbear is capable of gliding down from its perch in large trees where it nests, collapsing on its prey, which consists of large rodents and smaller mammals.

Owlbears have great sight in the dark and so prefer to hunt at night or in the thick shade of the forest's canopies. They often stay away from people and are timid in that regard, but will engage if threatened. They can be a great danger to even powerful mages when angered.

content.title: Springmane
paragraphs: The Springmane is a maned wolf-like native of Durlan that is considered by many to be the most beautiful creature in Edenfell (“Today, you are as fine as a Springmane, my dear!”). They are usually a single color (most often white) and have a flourishing mane that attracts birds, fireflies, and butterflies. They have a large pair of wooden, dendritic antlers that sprout cherry blossom petals. Springmanes carry a sweet scent with them, and their fur is more powerful and fragrant than most manufactured perfumes.

Springmanes only live for a few months, hatching in the spring and living through the summer until their petals and fur wither in the fall and they die, leaving behind the eggs of their offspring. The Alfen consider these creatures sacred, and Antler guards them ruthlessly due to their being sought after as attractions or for their fragrant fur. Springmanes communicate through eerie whistling sounds that form a melodic tune between them that is hauntingly beautiful when echoed over great distances.

content.title: Rubion
paragraphs: The Rubion is a colored fox with a single crystalline horn on its head in the color of a ruby. It lives in burrows in Durlan, Caliburn, and Vatha, and is one of the rarest creatures to spot in Edenfell due to its swiftness and elusive nature. As a result, not much is known about these creatures. They shed their rubies occasionally, leaving a trail that greedy poachers may follow to track them, though usually none are successful in doing so.

content.title: Elemental Dragons
paragraphs: Elemental dragons are one of the more ancient species in Edenfell. They are highly intelligent creatures, each possessing a unique and distinct personality. Some folk tales even speak of there being dragons that could produce speech and possess the intellect of an anthro.

Hundreds of years ago, before the Cataclysm had struck, elemental dragons were used as mounts and trusted companions of the Elves. Each Elf would have a companion dragon identical to their inherent elemental magic, creating a powerful duo that not just anyone could rival. Unfortunately, after the great calamity the dragons had suffered a change in nature; they had developed an aversion to mages. Now, instead of building bonds with the magical Elves, the dragons became aggressive towards anyone who is mana-sensitive. Nowadays, if one is lucky enough, only those who do not possess the gift of great mana can hope to gain the trust of a dragon.

The dragons mostly reside and can be found in Durlan, though thanks to their resilience and elemental nature, one can spot a dragon anywhere across Edenfell. Dragons prefer to nest and reproduce in biomes that correspond to their natural elemental affinity. These magnificent beasts can vary in size, being anywhere from the size of a horse to the size or cottage, with their size corresponding directly to their power (Tier).

paragraphs.text: Mostly in Durlan, but also seen in Caliburn, Vatha and Edom

content.title: Ice Lynx
paragraphs: Not much is known about the Ice Lynx as it is a recently discovered creature, so far only seen a few times in Caliburn. Adventurers are doing the best they can to find this unique cryptid so that they may learn all there is to know about the species.

content.title: Parhelion
paragraphs: Not much is known about the Parhelia as they are a recently discovered creature, so far only seen on one occasion in Durlan’s South. Adventurers believe this chimeraean to be the last relic of lost ancient history and is doing the best it can to find this unique cryptid so that they may learn all there is to know about the species.

content.title: Others
paragraphs: Other less fantastical beasts, such as leopards, elephants, gorillas, and tigers, can be found all over Edenfell. Most especially dogs which everyone is fond of and often take with them on long important journeys, missions, or even into battle.

content.title: Aureum
paragraphs: An Aureum flower can often be found in swamps or bodies of water which aren’t yet fully contaminated. Its petals work as lovely makeshift bandages, and will automatically wrap around any area that is bleeding. They heal slowly, but are a great temporary means of keeping wounds safe from infection.

content.title: Blue Bottoms
paragraphs: Blue Bottoms are a harmless plant found all over Edenfell, commonly used for their special trait of having many different flavours of taste despite their appearance. They can either be spicy, minty, fruity, etc., it all seems to be randomized, and all Blue Bottoms are identical in shape, so there's no telling on what kind they could truly be.

content.title: Celer
paragraphs: Celers are star-shaped flowers found typically near bodies of water around Edenfell, such as small ponds, streams, or even in big oceans. They stand tall with a yellow glow, and when entirely consumed will boost your physical speed. They give your tummy a funny butterfly feeling.

content.title: Esuriit Berries
paragraphs: Esuriit Berries only bloom in the warm enough months of the north, and are decently common to find in areas that allow it to be warm enough. These plants produce purple coloured berries and will replenish your hunger almost instantly when consumed. Very useful to have in any situation, but they only bloom for very short periods of time. When they're available to you, stock up on them before they mold.

content.title: Hiradym
paragraphs: This flower is used as the primary healing herb. By grinding the leaves and mixing them with tree sap, one gets an ornament that helps both disinfect and heal wounds. This is primarily used by hunters and travelers on their journeys and thankfully the flower can grow in even the harshest of environments, making the supply fit the large demand.

content.title: Golden Berries
paragraphs: Shortly after most Golden Apple Trees went extinct in the early days of the Cataclysm, determined Faes made it a duty to replicate them and return them in grand numbers. While that proved unsuccessful, they managed to create Golden Berries. They possess the ability to warp their taste to the consumer, tasting similar to one’s favorite dish. They also are noted to boost your morale, though one should be cautious with eating too many too quickly. These prove to be highly addictive.

content.title: Lantern Cherry
paragraphs: One of the only berries left in Edenfell. The Lantern Cherry is a tree that sprouts lantern-like branches and produces bundles of red cherries at the end. The trees can be found in the warmer climates of Edenfell and provide necessary nutrients for many of the tribes situated around them.

content.title: Snowy Delight
paragraphs: A tree that grows in the northern hemisphere of Edenfell. Instead of sprouting leaves, it collects snow at the end of its branches, and by mixing its natural sap with the snow, it ends up creating extremely sweet chilly spheres around the size of a basketball. The spheres do not weigh anything and melt easily, but if preserved right can be used as delicacy. It is closely tied to Nord culture and is often enjoyed during celebration.

content.title: Sunset Wheat
paragraphs: One of the more popular (and only) widespread grains found in Edenfell. Sunset Wheat is used to produce bread, beer and various other forms of pastry or dough. It can be found in places not touched by the Cataclysm too much, which means a lot of active tribes and cities were established next to their popular growing spots.

content.title: Pellucide
paragraphs: Pellucide fruits grow hidden away in dimly lit areas. They sprout from a glowing Pelli tree, usually also growing green crystals at its roots. The fruit itself is slightly bitter, though nourishing. However, when Pellucide get exposed to harsh lighting conditions, they crystallize into hard gems.

content.title: Martipea
paragraphs: Martipeas, often just nicknamed “martis”, are pear-shaped fruits ranging in various orange-yellow tones. Their taste, ironically enough, can be described as similar to honey.

content.title: Courtan
paragraphs: Originally discovered by mistake due to an explorer tripping over them, Courtans are nuts lining many forest floors. They start by growing deep underground, then eventually are pushed up to the surface by their roots. An extremely common addition to Edenfell.

content.title: Opertina
paragraphs: A common plant found around Durlan and Vatha, Opertinas are a nut and a vegetable combined in one. Their bottom, hard shells are farmed for grinding down into baking purposes. The green plants they sprout are often used for salads or other vegetable-related dishes.

content.title: Nircka
paragraphs: Typically hidden away by larger shrubs, Nirckas are mostly spotted by those with a trained eye for flora. They emit a soft, yellow light from their center. While their leaves are often used for tea, their middle must be avoided. When provoked, Nirckas release a blinding light, obscuring onlookers' vision for a singular turn.

content.title: Lacerta Cacti
paragraphs: Throughout the eastern desert, it's not uncommon to find harmless cacti growing. However, it's your best bet to be careful with the cacti you do find, just in case. Every so often, in a rare little patch, there's a deep, creaking plant beast hidden into the floor. When provoked (stepped on, crushed, poked, etc.), the desert floor will begin to tremble and a long reptilian-like plant beast will crawl out slowly from its position in the floor. The cacti creature has no eyes and is completely blind, but is covered in cacti needles that are constantly willing to prick you. Lacerta cacti are 2 meters in height and 5 meters long, from nose to tail.

content.title: Mimicking Marthas
paragraphs: Mimicking Marthas are scarcely found throughout a few locations of Edenfell, scattered around in hidden bushes. They’re a bushel of little flowers, with open petals at the tops of their stems. The flowers have a unique skill to mimic various sounds and even voices. While harmless by themselves, other more dangerous wildlife has learned to use the flowers as bait to lure in unsuspecting prey.

content.title: Rubrum Hedera
paragraphs: Rubrum Hedera is a wide plant with long 'tentacle' like attributes that can grow to be a meter and a half in height. They have small spiked ridges around them, and are mainly harmless unless you happen to touch their spikes. The inside of the plant growth, however, has neat red-magenta plants growing inside. Those plants, when touched to bare skin, will give an itchy rash for around 2-3 days, similar to poison ivy. When consumed, however, they are poisonous, and can be fatal when eaten too much.

content.title: Somnum’s Hypnosis
paragraphs: Somnum's Hypnosis are large flowers with big, broad leaves. The inside of the flower itself emits a gentle blue glow, and it's extremely pretty to look at, especially at night. Unfortunately, that is the plant's trick, and will keep you captivated the longer you look at it. The plant does no harm except for making you lose track of time completely, and by the time you're pulled away you can find yourself questioning how long you've been standing there staring at it. If you spend more than one turn looking at Somnum's Hypnosis, you will be hypnotized for 2 turns unless snapped out of it by someone else.

content.title: Venemum Swallowers
paragraphs: Venemum Swallowers are a large carnivorous plant that give off poisonous gasses in order to trap their prey. When still and unprovoked, they remain closed, and look like a tall, ordinary plant. However, when they sense something close enough to eat, their side parts slowly roll off of the center part of its body, and it emits a blue, visible poisonous gas. Once there’s enough of the poison in its prey's system, it grapples them by those same parts and opens up its center, drops it in, and feeds on it for nutrients. If a person is actively breathing in the gas for more than two turns and a half, you will be paralyzed. If grappled inside, you have a two turn opportunity to escape. If not grappled and still breathing in the poisonous gas after being paralyzed, it'll take you another two turns to die.

content.title: Splinter Sprinter
paragraphs: A harmless cacti that houses delicious water and soft and sweet interior beneath its hard and prickly green shell. Not particularly nutritious, but enough to keep a traveler hydrated, the cacti are an amazing find for most adventurers. Only issue is that the cacti can sprout four distinct legs when disturbed, and run at insanely high speeds, making it very hard to catch.

content.title: Grassza
paragraphs: A green plant that grows on the plains of southern Edenfell. It usually grows in pairs of two or three and bears the form of a pizza. The plant is delicious to eat and even warm due to absorbing the warmth of the soil inside of it.

content.title: Panacotta Flowers
paragraphs: As the name states, these are flowers that somehow grow small sweet cakes in the middle of the flower itself. They often attract tons of bees, butterflies and other sorts of critters that love sweets and pollen which is hidden inside the gelatin form of the cake.

content.title: The Azure Vacuum
paragraphs: A dangerous flower that perhaps takes its natural ability to absorb moisture a bit too seriously. Unlike normal plants that suck up water only enough to make itself live, this flower has a peculiar ability to rid something of any liquid in a matter of seconds. It usually grows in wet and moist soil, but leaves the area around it completely dry. Anyone unfortunate enough to be caught in the grasp of this plant’s tentacles will find themselves extremely dehydrated, or dead, if they don’t react quickly.

content.title: Sidus(i)
paragraphs: The Sidus plant (or Sidusi, plurally) are delicious star-shaped fruit found in Edenfell. Their space-like insides are sticky to the touch, common in jam and expensive dishes.

content.title: Cachinnate
paragraphs: Though they are scarcely found in the wild, Cachinnate seeds can be found in most magical shops for high prices. They seem to be harvested in secret in order to prevent mass mishaps. When their blue/purple growths are plucked and thrown, they explode upon impact, sending out a powdery explosion of color. If inhaled, Cachinnates will cause uncontrollable laughter for one turn.

paragraphs.text: Found in Magic Shops for high prices, and rarely in the wild on the edges of Corrupted Forests

content.title: Pinespike
paragraphs: After the great Cataclysm, some plants in Edenfell that were already dangerous became outright lethal. Before one had to worry about half-conscious greenery that acted on pure outside stimuli, but with the collision of the worlds, certain plants evolved past that and developed instincts comparable to wild animals.

These humanoid plants with pine heads inhabit the areas most affected by the cataclysm. They live in hoards and survive on the toxic waters in the surrounding areas. The inside of their pine heads hides an extremely delicious and delicate seed that can enrich any dish and provide enough nutrients to last someone an entire week. Unfortunately, getting the seed is more than most are ready to bargain for.

content.title: Lumishrooms
paragraphs: A previously widespread type of mushroom that now hides in little known parts of Edenfell’s natural habitats. The mushroom can be found all across the continent, growing in even the harshest conditions. While it has very low nutritional value, it is used to create various potent antidotes. By mixing the mushroom with the target poison, it is able to create a potent antidote, eliminating the effects of the poison when consumed.

content.title: The Reaper Mushroom
paragraphs: If the name doesn’t make you take a full turn and leave, hopefully the appearance will. Reaper Mushroom is the most toxic plant found in Edenfell, a single mushroom having enough poison inside of it to take down dozens of anthros. The peculiar trait of this shroom is that it’s practically odorless and if prepared right, can be edible. The shroom needs to be steamed over fire for hours, after which it is grilled over hot coal until its texture becomes completely crispy. If the mushroom is prepared wrong, it will instantly produce a disgustingly bitter taste in one’s mouth, though, by then it’s already too late. The mushroom is found deep inside dark and moist caverns near bodies of water.

paragraphs.text: Border of Werewick and Red Woods

content.title: Lunamis
paragraphs: Only able to grow beneath the full moon, Lunamis are very rare melons that simply take one night to blossom. Upon consumption, the eater will be granted night vision for approximately five hours. If also consumed on a full moon, said person will feel a minor buff to their stats (+1 tier for 5 turns).

content.title: Eve's Ribcage
paragraphs: Ominously looming over scarce bodies of water, Ribcages find themselves covered in blood, relying on vampiric tendencies to survive. When the sensors on their petals (their “bones”) are triggered by the sensation of a pulse, they begin to thrash around wildly, revealing their prickly middle that attacks their prey with repetitive slashes.

content.title: Lirania
paragraphs: Lirania is a rare plant that turns deadly in the light. This plant is harmless until it is hit by the suns rays. As a nocturnal flower, it has adapted to the moonlight. As such, when it is touched by the light of the sun, it has a negative affect, causing the flower to hold poisonous properties.

content.title: Verimawe
paragraphs: Horrific in appearance, The Verimawe resembles a talking mangled tree. While it remains to be found (and is dubiously real), the legend goes that The Verimawe is capable of restoring all flora to a state of excellency all over Edenfell. Most believe it was just a myth created by Faes in hopes of fixing what once was.

content.title: Golden Apple Tree
paragraphs: Golden Apple Trees are exactly what they sound like. Not too different from regular apple trees, these trees merely sprout golden fruit that glow brightly. The trees had gone almost fully extinct after the Cataclysm, yet few remained, saved by being located in the old Alfenheim’s private orchards. Currently the trees can be mostly found grown inside the walls of Durlan’s capital, closely tended by Illumi Fëanor.
The Golden Apples themselves do not possess any special properties besides being sweeter and a bit bigger than normal apples. The importance of the trees is solely tied to sentimental value.

Small towns and villages make up the majority of the realm, which is currently governed by the cities of Durlan, Caliburn, Vatha, and Edom. The inhabitants of Edenfell are served and safeguarded by these cities, which also uphold their core values. The four cities are generally independent states, but all of them—aside from Durlan—are united under the same Trident flag since Durlan is seen as their common enemy and a threat to civic freedom. On the grounds of the tournament, the Trident cities may have passionate rivalries, but they rarely engage in open hostilities and have never declared war on one another.

content.title: Antiquity
paragraphs: Some folk legends claim that the five relics that now form the centers of the cities (and the edge of the Red Woods) were Elvish treasures back then, and it's even possible that Elven magic created some of them. But the only veritable source from the time before the Cataclysm doesn’t remember these relics ever being around before Nimiane shattered the world.

The relics themselves are amazing, enigmatic artifacts with tremendous magical power and a level of awareness that is just beyond our comprehension today. There is no doubt that each of the five relics is a physical representation of one of the five virtues and has the authority to judge that virtue in people. The relics' qualities (and judgment) are viewed as being immutable and objective in Edenfell, and the majority of society is based on their infallibility.

content.title: The Five Virtues
paragraphs: Five fundamental virtues—loyalty, wisdom, tenacity, bravery, and strength—rule life in Edenfell. Knights, nobles, and commoners all make an effort to uphold these ideals in their daily lives. In addition to employing racially and ethnically driven profanities, people in the realm frequently mention their success or inability to uphold a certain virtue when they want to praise or condemn someone.

The five virtues are established by the five relics and are thusly treated with absolute respect and authority. The denizens of the realm see all the virtues as ideals to strive for, but not always equally. Naturally, each city believes the virtue associated with their own relic is paramount, though, not in lieu of the others. A knight of Caliburn will admire your courage above all else but still look down upon the disloyal or foolish.

content.title: Knights of the United Army (UnA)
paragraphs: Knighthood is one of the highest distinctions one can attain in the Trident. As champions, heroes, and role models of morality, knights are adored. All knights of the realm, who are addressed with the honorific 'Syr', have a variety of duties, from enforcing the law in their communities and safeguarding defenseless citizens to undertaking dangerous missions to stop and capture Voidbringers who venture too near settlements or cities. They frequently act as scouts, roving the countryside searching for Higher Sentient or Voidborn. Knights frequently ride noble steeds of various sizes and kinds, wear exquisitely constructed armor and weapons, and on occasion, if they are mages (UnA mages are often called spellswords), use potent magic.

A quest to demonstrate excellence in one of the city's virtues is required to become a knight in one of the Trident cities. In some cities, the last stage to becoming a true knight is to be assessed by the relic of that city.

content.title: Durlan
paragraphs: Durlan is perched on top of a hill in the far south, gazing out over the fields and pastures of the towns below. Acres of perfectly trimmed lawns and pristine, verdant gardens are enclosed within its tall white walls. Dozens of faithful guards surround the Ring of Loyalty, which is located towards the top of the main castle's central tower.

Due to its population being primarily made up of settlement dwellers in the outer city who exchange some of their labor from foraging, herding, and other artisan and working-class crafts for the protection provided by the relatively few mages who live in the inner city, Durlan is the smallest city by population. About 300 mages live in the inner city of Durlan, and Mage Seekers and the mages they accompany form campaign groups. Families of visiting mages are given temporary housing inside the city's walls, and only the relatives of the highest-ranking officials are given permanent housing there. Non-mages are only permitted inside the city's walls if they perform necessary services that keep the city running smoothly and support a functioning civilization.

Durlan, ironically, considers itself a beacon of peace and resistance against the spreading arcane corruption in the realm, standing as both a symbolic and literal object of power. Its mages like to say that merely speaking the city’s name will weave subtle magic of protection around the speaker and their allies. The castle is home to King Fëanor, Durlan’s ruler.

content.title: Loyalty
paragraphs: Loyalty is the fundamental characteristic on which Durlan is based. Although its powerful and authoritative manner of approach would suggest that preaching and practice are very different, the city views loyalty as a foundation of kinship and trust that supports the other virtues, rather than merely mindless obedience to whoever happens to be in control.

True harmony among people cannot exist without the capacity for trust and loyalty, and true virtue cannot exist without harmony. Due to its tendency to erode the basis of mutual respect and harmony, ego is the adversary of loyalty. As a result, Durlanite mages try to perfect their virtue by putting aside their own desires and thoughts. As a Higher Sentient, leaving the city is considered desertion, and those found guilty would be marked as wanted and executed.

content.title: Durlan’s Mages and Mage Seekers: The Higher Sentient
paragraphs: The Higher Sentient Army, which is ruthlessly efficient and frequently cruel in its convictions, includes all of Durlan's Mages. Above all things, the Mages of Durlan are devoted to their city's leaders, to one another, and to the entire populace that makes up the city. The name Higher Sentient is derived from the ideology that mages are the next step in Anthro evolution and a higher form of individual than the common man could ever be. Durlan’s mages try to exemplify this condescendingly self-righteous ideology by following their strict moral code and societal structure to the letter of the law. Their allegiance outweighs any haughtiness or sense of superiority; triumph belongs to the collective, not to any one person, and even the glory of a single mage benefits Durlan as a whole.

The army of the Higher Sentient is made up entirely of mages, who are organized into units that include a Mage Seeker—a mage who specializes in finding potential mages—and a diverse group of mages to support the seeker. The Higher Sentient typically participates in patrolling the kingdom of Durlan to maintain the safety of the outlying villages and to look for any burgeoning young mages (often snatched from their resisting parents’ arms) who can be brought to the capital and trained to join its ranks.

When battling in a group, Durlanite mages are even more fierce than they are individually. Due to loyalty, they almost never go on missions by themselves, ensuring that no mage is ever abandoned and captured by the enemy. Durlan's mages enjoy congregating at the court for the arts, company, and conversation—treasures they value beyond all others—when not engaged in combat or on solitary quests in the wild.

Settlers seek out Durlan as much as any of the Trident cities as it provides a larger and safer body of protection for them as opposed to staying in their hamlets scattered around the continent at the mercy of prowling Voidbringers. Though they are not regarded as the equals of the mages and are often relegated to the outer city, commoners in Durlan are treated with a higher level of egalitarianism and equity than in the other cities as Durlan’s society is harmonious and has been free of the conflicts that arise from politics and misplaced ambition thus far, thanks to its virtue. It also helps that Durlan’s outer city which encircles the opulent inner city is not far behind in splendor or comfort.

content.title: The Ring of Loyalty
paragraphs: At the heart of Durlan’s main castle is a magical ring of eternally burning silver fire known as the Ring of Loyalty. To be named a member of the Higher Sentient, aspirants must walk through the flame, for its magic can detect selfish people and undesirable motives. Those who pass through the flame unscathed are deemed worthy and christened at the center of the ring itself. Those who are burned are quickly pulled out and healed, but rarely are they allowed to attempt the trial a second time. Failure to pass the test means suffering shame as a steward of the Higher Sentient’s members as one cannot just leave.

content.title: King Fëanor, the Fireforged
paragraphs: Durlan is an absolute monarchy ruled by the only known living Anthro from before the cataclysm: Illumi Fëanor.

Fëanor is a tall, imposing elf, often towering even over most others of his own kind. An immaculate specimen of the Alfen from before the Cataclysm, Fëanor takes great pride in representing the best of what his race used to be, often regaling in talks of the old traditions and spawning nuggets of wisdom from his tales.

Shrewd, cunning, brutal and tenacious. Fëanor, as the head of the Higher Sentient, is known for his ruthlessness and his unfaltering focus on finding and spawning new mages in order to eradicate the Voidbringer threat once and for all.
He demands absolute loyalty from all his subjects, and does not hesitate in eliminating those who step out of line.
As the first and only King of Durlan since the kingdom’s inception, Fëanor is the subject of many old wives tales, and as such, scrutinizing the truth from the myth is a tall task.

content.title: Caliburn
paragraphs: Caliburn rises like an island above Everstill, a mist-shrouded lake on top of a highland in the west, a barrier constructed by the Elves to keep the Voidbringers out. Water freely flows throughout the fortress like a lavish fountain, and banners and pennants flutter from its spires. This lake is created by a mountain gap that is regularly filled with water, and the castle is perched on top of a sizable shaft in the middle of the lake. The Looking Glass is located in a murky, cavernous area at the bottom of this shaft.

Researchers and inquirers from the other cities frequently travel the challenging distance to Caliburn since it is recognized as a hub of scholarship in the Trident and holds information that cannot be accessed elsewhere.

content.title: Wisdom
paragraphs: The knights of Caliburn consider wisdom to be the highest virtue. wisdom guides the right application of every other virtue in a variety of situations and aids in preventing problems from getting worse and becoming more serious.

The mastery of facts is only one aspect of wisdom. The ability to combine diverse data to gain a deeper grasp of systems and principles is what distinguishes actual wisdom from a dispersed collection of unrelated facts. Wisdom's enemies include not only ignorance and foolishness but also narrow-mindedness and tradition-bound ways of thinking. The Caliburn knights must be able to modify their worldview in response to fresh knowledge and concepts.

content.title: Caliburn's UnA Knights
paragraphs: In Caliburn, knighthood is wisdom applied to the challenges of the world. To become a knight, an aspirant must tell the Looking Glass a truth it did not already know, and even then, the gift of knighthood is bestowed at the Glass’ inscrutable discretion. Once that gift is bestowed, the knights of Caliburn continue to seek out new secrets for the Looking Glass, but they also venture out into the world and the wilds to put their wisdom to use. Alongside their combat duties, many of them strive to help those who are in need of wisdom. When someone is stumped by a riddle, can't bypass an enchanted door, or is enthralled by witchcraft, a knight of Caliburn might arrive to help them out of their predicament.

content.title: Lorechasers
paragraphs: The lorechasers of Caliburn (also known as chroniclers or riddle-seekers) look for wildlore and delve into the mysteries of the complicated magic of the Voidborn. They are astonishingly brave and experienced scholars, and it happens frequently for knights from every city to venture into a lonely swamp or explore a cave lit only by fireflies only to discover a lorechaser of Caliburn already there. They are skilled in negotiating agreements with supernatural beings, deciphering runes, and determining the objectives and outcomes of rituals. A word of caution: be prepared to bear their answers in excruciating detail when you visit a chronicler of lore.

content.title: The Looking Glass
paragraphs: The secret-hoarding Looking Glass is located well beneath Caliburn's Council House in a cavern that is often flooded. Only people who live in Caliburn refer to it by its real name, Gogoth. According to legend, the world's most foolish goblin (something called a durandal) once asked the world's wisest sage a question. For the remainder of his life, the sage thought about this query without coming up with a solution. After his passing, the query mysteriously persisted, converging in on itself, and the Looking Glass materialized. Everyone but the Glass is unaware of the question, but the Glass nevertheless sends loremages and knights on mystical scavenger hunts in hopes that one day it will piece together the solution.

The Looking Glass evaluates the virtue of wisdom in all who come before it. This is examined by the Council of Ten before a knight is appointed. Even experienced knights bring new secrets to the Glass in the hopes of receiving magical boons and powers as additional rewards; yet, despite the legend, no one has ever received such a reward. Though the Looking Glass's entire potential is unknown, there is no denying the breadth of its knowledge when it chooses to answer.

Caliburn is governed by a multi-racial council composed of ten revered individuals. This diverse Council of Ten, chosen not for their race or social standing but solely for their exceptional expertise and profound knowledge in their respective domains, wields authority over the city. The selection process is guided by the arcane Looking Glass as it transcends biases and assesses the council members' deep wisdom. Ideally, with their vast knowledge and unparalleled understanding, this esteemed council leads Caliburn with an unwavering commitment to collective well-being, making informed decisions that shape the realm's flourishing future.

content.title: Vatha
paragraphs: Forged by the hands of giants in an era predating Anthros' dominion, Vatha stands as an enigmatic realm, adorned with colossal and peculiar structures. At its core lies the Menhir, a relic of remarkable magnitude perched upon a prominent stone outcrop. Embracing the Menhir, the city expands, a testament to the Nords and Faes who, after the Cataclysm, erected a human-scaled enclave encircling the ancient relic. Here, the fusion of massive stone, mortal craftsmanship, and untamed growth coalesce in harmonious unity.

Like a celestial timekeeper, the central stone of Vatha assumes the mantle of a sundial's gnomon. During specific celestial alignments, the encircling monoliths align with the celestial bodies' paths, briefly unveiling a gateway to the profound and shadowed recesses of Edenfell, where secrets dwell in the deepest darkness. When not covered in snow (which isn’t often), Vatha’s lands are lush though not as forested as the west around Caliburn and Edenfell’s south.

content.title: Strength
paragraphs: Above all, the knights of Vatha hold raw physical strength in the highest esteem. A Vathan knight must possess the prowess to wield colossal weapons, don the weightiest armor, and showcase feats of strength that verge on the superhuman. While the strength of will and character are also valued, they are seen as complementary to physical power, not substitutes.

Strength, being the most overt of virtues, molds the very fabric of the Vathan perspective. Action reigns paramount, overshadowing intention and desire. Those who fixate on their inner lives and personal virtue without translating them into tangible deeds are regarded with disapproval.

content.title: Vatha's UnA Knights
paragraphs: To ascend to the esteemed rank of a Vathan knight, one must exhibit a formidable display of strength, surpassing the expectations set by their stature and race. The ruler of the court, the discerning arbiter of knighthood, is none other than Jarl Thrawn, whose standards are exceptionally high, resulting in a scarcity of knights within Vatha.

Those who have attained the coveted title of knighthood revel in their robust might, employing it readily even in endeavors deemed less knightly by the other Trident cities. Vathan knights can often be found engaging in wrestling matches and confronting formidable beasts within the depths of the forest. Yet, they are equally likely to be seen participating in acts of community service, such as bearing water in a fire brigade or clearing fallen trees after a tempestuous storm. The knights hold a fondness for tales and competitions that unfold in the grand hall of Vatha Castle, but their true calling lies beyond its confines, where they tirelessly extend their aid and safeguard the vulnerable and virtuous souls that dwell in the world.

content.title: The Menhir
paragraphs: Contrary to its name, the Menhir comprises a grand assembly of colossal stone monoliths arranged in diverse shapes and patterns, contingent upon the time of visitation. At the heart of this henge, a solitary mountainous slab commands the center stage, serving as the gnomon of a prodigious sundial. During select dates, at sunrise and sunset, the encompassing monoliths cast shadows in such a manner that the central stone transforms into a mystical gateway, leading to unknown depths of Edenfell. The encircling calendar stones can be lifted and repositioned to synchronize with the desired time and destination for this extraordinary voyage. Merely shifting a single monolith, even slightly, stands as an astonishing feat of strength, while maneuvering multiple stones into their precise locations to unlock the portal virtually assures the attainment of Vathan knighthood.

If a person passes through at sunrise and doesn't come back at sunset, they might come back after a year and a day; if they don't come back then, they are probably lost forever…or they can just walk back.

content.title: Jarl Thrawn
paragraphs: Nords usually reside in the colder regions north of Edenfell and are often large, burly fellows with a thickness of hair that makes the biting cold no more than a pesky inconvenience. Vatha is an absolute monarchy and has always been ruled by a Jarl.

The current Jarl of Vatha is the giant Nord named Thrawn, who towers over even others of his kind and has a mane and mantle of curiously green hair.
